reviews.title: Nice Korea town
text: My wife is Korean so I found this area so she could do some shopping and find some dinner. We don’t have a Korea town where we live so this was a great treat.

reviews.title: Great experience to know other cultures!
text: beautiful neighborhood, plenty of ethnic restaurants and at side of Christie Subway Station. University students, young and vibrant environment!

reviews.title: Nice stroll
text: This was a nice stroll coming from Chinatown and Kensington.  Korea town is full of shops and restaurants.

reviews.title: a lot of cute restaurants and a lot of shopping possibilities
text: like this place. we stayed in this area during our visit of toronto. it‘t sometimes very busy bit there are a lot of cute places. just walk around and look around

reviews.title: Lots of bars and shops!
text: Here you can visit lots of stores, bars and great restaurants. In addition, there are a few nice parks.

reviews.title: Great food at affordable prices
text: I love Koreatown! It is small but the restaurants will give you an authentic Korean experience. Be sure to visit some of the shops as well to stock up on Korean treats and other goods. It is a very budget friendly neighborhood.

reviews.title: Great place to get food..
text: If you ever start craving Korean food, this is the place to go. It's located close to the subway, just ride the train to Bathurst Station. Bunch of Korean restaurants, desserts, general stores to visit. There's even Karaoke lounge and full Korean super market here.

reviews.title: Small and Busy
text: Packed with restaurants and food choices. Small area and easy to walk around. Some very nice stationary/gift stores. K-pop staff we only found in Just you Sarah and Tom. Also you might want to try the Poop Cafe. Can't depend on the business hours though, some stores are way late to open

reviews.title: A rarity
text: Sitting snuggly along Bloor St between Christie and Bathurst Station is Koreatown...the closest onne that I have encountered outside of South Korea. When I was there during the evening, even the aroma of spicy Korean cooking was present! Both sides of the street was lined with Korean restaurants (and a few Japanese too), groceries and other trinklet stores. Other than the presence of English signages, one would easily take this place as in S Korea!

reviews.title: Koreatown
text: Korea town is filled with a lot of amazing food to try and a lot of stuff to do that you wouldn't normally do. I recommend going and getting lost in Koreatown

reviews.title: Koreatown is great dining
text: I've lived in Toronto much of my life and finally explored Koreatown. The food is incredible, so I look forward to going back often.

reviews.title: Worth a wander
text: We strolled through here and it was worth a good walk round. A large number of Korean places to eat and drink. Some looked better than others. My partner loved the fish shaped pancakes that u can pick up at the side of the road, either filled with red bean or custard. Was just like being back in Seoul.

reviews.title: Good to hangout
text: We usually visit Korea town when we feel like having good Korean dishes. After dinner we would go out for some karaoke sessions!

reviews.title: Cheap and good food
text: This stretch of Bloor Street, from Christie Pits to Bathurst Street is home to a number of inexpensive Korean restaurants, supermarkets and some karaoke restaurants.  There is another Koreatown in Toronto (around Yonge and Finch), but I prefer this one.

reviews.title: Koreatown - a great Toronto neighbourhood to explore
text: Koreatown is a great neighbourhood for locals and visitors alike to explore in Toronto!  The Christie subway stop and the Bathurst subway stations are super convenient, and Little Italy, the Annex, and Bloorcourt neighbourhoods are all nearby.
Here are a few of my favourite suggestions of places to check out (full disclaimer...I'm lucky enough to live in this neighbourhood):
-Clinton's: great food (you can get pretty much everything vegetarian, including the gravy), dance parties on the weekend, and other special events like Choir, Choir, Choir, the World Cup, etc.

-Buk Chang Dong Soon Tofu: Korean place across the street from Clintons (on the south side): In my opinion, definitely the best Korean restaurant on the street. There is often a line, but it moves quickly...but there are so many others to try too.
-Tacos El Sador: everyone loves this place for authentic "Mexican" food - they are actually from El Salvador

-Christie Pitts Park: great park for hanging out; there is a skating rink in the winter, this is where the Toronto Maple Leaf BASEBALL team plays (usually on Sundays, and always for free), a pizza oven that is used during festivals, a folk festival, a Korean festival, a Latino festival, the David Suzuki Foundation's Garrison Creek Walk, and so much more
-P.A.T.: the Korean grocery store.  If you want a small taste of Korea this is a good taste; a great place to buy frozen dumplings, ginger ice cream, kimchee, and so so much more

-Fish Waffles: inside the PAT.  There is no fish in these waffles, just yummy custard or sweet bean filling.  I think the red bean is most traditional, but most 'non-Korean Canadians' seem to like the custard. Get two, they are that good!
-Pour Boys: just north of Bloor on Manning.  Super cheap, good drinks.  I think it is cash only.
-Shopping: so many stores, lots of Korean ones with interesting stuff, but a few Latino ones opened up lately.  Check them all out.
-Veggie markets: the one at Bloor and Manning is a destination.  Super cheap. There are a bunch of others too.

-Qi: a natural food store (two actually: both on north side of the street, one just east of Christie, one just west of Bathurst).  These places give the natural food stores in Kensington a run for their money
-Mirvish Village: on Markham south of Bloor.  A number of restaurants and other interesting stores. The Victory has a great patio and is a classic.
-Kop's Records & Doug Miller Books: both awesome places to check out
-Hodo Kwaja: Korean walnut cakes...a classic, as is the nearby Bubble Tea place

-Sam James Coffee: their "pocket" location is on the north side of Bloor just east of Clinton.  This is another destination place.  Their larger, and original location, is on Harbord also just east of Clinton.

-Honest Ed's: if you haven't been in before, go now.. It's slated to close Dec 2016 and is an icon of Toronto.  It's at the corner of Bloor & Bathurst.  There is a Wine Rack conveniently located here too.
All this, and so much more all within five blocks, makes it a great place to spend the afternoon. Have fun!!

reviews.title: Worth a visit
text: the restaurants are very good, cheap and there are lots of them.  The Korean Village is the place for fancy but you can just as easily grab a bowl of pork bone soup in a more casual setting.  The locals are friendly and like to help.  Some interesting shops, especially the Japanese paper shop which sells some beautiful cards at ridiculously low prices.  Honest Ed's stands on the edge of the hood, a landmark, and maybe worth a visit.  P.A.T grocery store is also worth a stop....huge assortment of foodstuffs.  Pleasant hood for a stroll.

reviews.title: Great place to head if you want authentic Asian food
text: We had a delicious lunch here and enjoyed walking the area, even in the cold November weather.  There are some great shops, including the huge Ed's super bargain center.  We grabbed some more wine at a wine store there, and would definitely go back to spend more time.

reviews.title: I enjoyed it
text: Toronto's Koreatown is similar to those in other cities with Korean immigrant populations and it's generally fun. Korean restaurants and shops selling stuffed Korean toys and K-Pop abound. The whole Bloor area nearby is worth a stroll. The area seems trendy without being too cool for the mainstream.

reviews.title: Small but packed!
text: We're from out of town and wondered if there was a koreatown in Toronto. I heard there were a lot of Asians but not every city with a lot of Asians has a koreatown. To my surprise there was and although it is only a few blocks long it is packed. A grocery store with a fish shaped bread stall there that is delicious!  We tried the custard and the green bean, both yummy!  A lot of different restaurants to choose from and a few cute stationary stores too. A hodo gwaja place that makes them on the spot and it is YUMMY. Would definitely visit again if in town.

reviews.title: A lil fun and adventure
text: Bloor Street West, between Bathurst and Christie. Great fun to browse through small boutiques and shops, tea houses and how about some Korean barbecue, kimchee, tofu soup, etc. Had a great lunch @ Kachi and some tea at the tea house nearby. One of the shops we found accidentally and fell in love right away was called "Hanji" selling loads of handmade paper goods and gifts. Everything was so cute and unique, and I picked up some cards and letter sets:)

reviews.title: Happy surprise
text: Went to Toronto for a combined business/pleasure day trip.  Ended up in Korea Town with time to spare and two little kids.  It was fun!  Shops were neat and everyone was very polite.  Never felt stupid for asking about an item or something I didn't know/couldn't read.
Special shout out to Just for You Sarah and Tom (near Bloor and Euclid).  The staff are SO lovely and we're great with the kids.  Definitely a highlight of the day.

reviews.title: Good Place to Explore
text: We spent quite a bit of time walking around Koreatown, and it was pretty cool! We really liked the sort of cutesy shops with stickers, stationary, plushies, etc., and the food was pretty good too. We had lunch at Mom's Korean Food because we noticed quite a few Korean people inside, and it was pretty good. We then had bubble tea and boong-uh-ppang (fish-shaped waffles with custard and red bean filling). Overall, visiting Koreatown made for a fun afternoon.

reviews.title: Best Kimchi!
text: If you like Kimchi then this is the area to go to get it.  There a couple of Korean grocery stores that I visit on regular basis.  Plus, while you are there, feel free to stop at one of the several really good Korean restaurants.  Do some menu shopping while you walk through the area and just pick a place, you won't be disappointed.

reviews.title: Nice
text: While staying in Toronto for a few days, I had to go to Koreatown.. My daughter is teaching in Korea and I wanted to get a feel for where she is. This is a nice place to visit, the stores and restaurants are great.

reviews.title: Culture
text: I went here with a friend who has spent a lot of time in Korea.  He loved the shops and food.  I can't remember the places we ate, but he was extremely satisfied with each of the meals and the snacks we bought.

reviews.title: some great restaurants and interesting shops here
text: I have never been to a Korean town so I thought why not visit! It was not disappointing and it seemed nicer than the China town in Toronto which is where my hotel was. It had a large selection of restaurants and some interesting stores. There were some great stores selling different things from the cute side of Asian culture and places that sold K-pop mixed in with the everyday life things. Korea apparently has a lot of spicy food so keep that in mind if you don't like that, but if you want Asian food or are into Asian culture I think you will like this better than China town.

reviews.title: no big deal
text: we walked around koreatown it was no big deal would walk around again would not make a special trip .

reviews.title: OK for a nice walk or dinner
text: Stumble across this while going for a walk from my hotel on Bloor. Just three blocks down found out that I had entered Koreatown. While it made for a nice walk, went about ten blocks, cannot say that the area really stood out. Mostly restaurants so I guess if you are looking for Korean food then this is the place. However, not nearly as distinctive as say Chinatown in Chicago.
